newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Sweden's Riksbank cuts key rate, more expected.
newsitem.headline: Sweden's Riksbank cuts key rate, more expected.

text.p: Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, Tuesday surprised financial markets with a larger-than-expected 0.25 percentage point cut in a key interest rate, and analysts forecast more cuts before the year's end.
The Riksbank trimmed its repo rate to 4.35 percent, exceeding most analysts' expectations, which ranged between 0.05 and 0.25 points, saying inflation remained on target.

Riksbank governor Urban Backstrom on Monday said he was satisfied with inflationary data over the past month, with Swedish consumer prices unchanged in October and producing a year-on-year rate of minus 0.1 percent. It was the first time since 1959 that Sweden has seen prices fall.
With all signs pointing to inflation staying under control in the near future, analysts said the Riksbank could cut its repo rate at least one more time in 1996.
"There will be new speculation about further repo rate cuts because fundamentals show there's still potential for further monetary easing," Unibank Markets analyst Bjorn Englund said.

The Riksbank said the cut to the repo rate, the bank's key tool for controlling money market liquidity, was permissible because inflation was in line with its target of 2 percent with a one percentage point variance in either direction.
"The Riksbank judges that the outlook for inflation continues to be in line with the inflation target," the bank said in a statement.
The deposit and lending rates currently stand at 4.25 percent and 5.75 percent. They were last lowered by 0.50 percentage points on Oct. 24.
